This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `m` and `n`, `m` divides `n` if and only if the integer representation of `m` divides the integer representation of `n`. Here, `‚Üëm` and `‚Üën` denote the integer representations of the natural numbers `m` and `n`, respectively. The `‚àÄ` symbol denotes universality, meaning that the statement holds for all instances of `m` and `n`. The `‚à£` symbol represents the divides relation.

type: ‚àÄ {m n : ‚Ñï}, ‚Üëm ‚à£ ‚Üën ‚Üî m ‚à£ n
name: Int.ofNat_dvd
docString: This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `m` and `n`, `m` divides `n` if and only if the integer representation of `m` divides the integer representation of `n`. Here, `‚Üëm` and `‚Üën` denote the integer representations of the natural numbers `m` and `n`, respectively. The `‚àÄ` symbol denotes universality, meaning that the statement holds for all instances of `m` and `n`. The `‚à£` symbol represents the divides relation.

For any `y < 1` and any positive `x`, there exists `n : ‚Ñï` with `y ^ n < x`.

For every positive number x and y > 1 in a linear ordered Archimedean semifield Œ±, there exists an integer n such that 0 < y^n < x <= y^(n+1).

docString: For every positive number x and y > 1 in a linear ordered Archimedean semifield Œ±, there exists an integer n such that 0 < y^n < x <= y^(n+1).

This theorem states that for any type `Œ±` that is a commutative monoid, the "divides" relation (`x` divides `x_1`) is equivalent to the "less than or equal to" relation (`x` is less than or equal to `x_1`). In other words, for any two elements in a commutative monoid, saying that one element divides the other is the same as saying that the one element is less than or equal to the other.

type: ‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : CommMonoid Œ±], (fun x x_1 => x ‚à£ x_1) = fun x x_1 => x ‚â§ x_1
name: Associates.dvd_eq_le

In other words, for any two elements in a commutative monoid, saying that one element divides the other is the same as saying that the one element is less than or equal to the other.

Induction principle for intervals of real numbers: if a proposition `P` is true
on `[x‚ÇÄ, r * x‚ÇÄ)` and if `P` for `[x‚ÇÄ, r^n * x‚ÇÄ)` implies `P` for `[r^n * x‚ÇÄ, r^(n+1) * x‚ÇÄ)`,
then `P` is true for all `x ‚â• x‚ÇÄ`.

type:
‚àÄ {P : ‚Ñù ‚Üí Prop} (x‚ÇÄ r : ‚Ñù),
  1 < r ‚Üí
    0 < x‚ÇÄ ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico x‚ÇÄ (r * x‚ÇÄ), P x) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ n ‚â• 1, (‚àÄ z ‚àà Set.Ico x‚ÇÄ (r ^ n * x‚ÇÄ), P z) ‚Üí ‚àÄ z ‚àà Set.Ico (r ^ n * x‚ÇÄ) (r ^ (n + 1) * x‚ÇÄ), P z) ‚Üí
          ‚àÄ x ‚â• x‚ÇÄ, P x
name: Real.induction_Ico_mul
docString:
Induction principle for intervals of real numbers: if a proposition `P` is true
on `[x‚ÇÄ, r * x‚ÇÄ)` and if `P` for `[x‚ÇÄ, r^n * x‚ÇÄ)` implies `P` for `[r^n * x‚ÇÄ, r^(n+1) * x‚ÇÄ)`,
then `P` is true for all `x ‚â• x‚ÇÄ`.

Technical lemma to control the addition of functions in `L^p` even for `p < 1`: Given `Œ¥ > 0`,
there exists `Œ∑` such that two functions bounded by `Œ∑` in `L^p` have a sum bounded by `Œ¥`. One
could take `Œ∑ = Œ¥ / 2` for `p ‚â• 1`, but the point of the lemma is that it works also for `p < 1`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} (E : Type u_2) {m0 : MeasurableSpace Œ±} (Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±) [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  (p : ENNReal) {Œ¥ : ENNReal},
  Œ¥ ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
    ‚àÉ Œ∑,
      0 < Œ∑ ‚àß
        ‚àÄ (f g : Œ± ‚Üí E),
          MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable f Œº ‚Üí
            MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable g Œº ‚Üí
              MeasureTheory.snorm f p Œº ‚â§ Œ∑ ‚Üí MeasureTheory.snorm g p Œº ‚â§ Œ∑ ‚Üí MeasureTheory.snorm (f + g) p Œº < Œ¥
name: MeasureTheory.exists_Lp_half
docString:

could take `Œ∑ = Œ¥ / 2` for `p ‚â• 1`, but the point of the lemma is that it works also for `p < 1`.

Let `M` be a smooth œÉ-compact manifold with a metric. Let `K : Œπ ‚Üí Set M` be a locally finite
family of closed sets, let `U : Œπ ‚Üí Set M` be a family of open sets such that `K i ‚äÜ U i` for all
`i`. Then there exists a positive smooth function `Œ¥ : M ‚Üí ‚Ñù‚â•0` such that for any `i` and `x ‚àà K i`,
we have `Metric.closedBall x (Œ¥ x) ‚äÜ U i`.

type:

  (‚àÄ (i : Œπ), IsClosed (K i)) ‚Üí

name: Metric.exists_smooth_forall_closedBall_subset
docString:

Let `X` be a metric space. Let `K : Œπ ‚Üí Set X` be a locally finite family of closed sets, let
